title-group.article-title: Thermal models for MTM45-1 and Cycom 5320 out-of-autoclave prepreg resins

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, McGill University, Canada
2Department of Materials Engineering, The University of British Columbia, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Pascal Hubert, Department of Mechanical Engineering, McGill University, 817 Sherbrooke Street West, Montreal, QC H3A 2K6, Canada. Email: pascal.hubert@mcgill.ca

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Out-of-autoclave prepregs require a two-step cure cycle. The first step is a low temperature cure to consolidate the laminate and build sufficient green strength to proceed to the second step, a free-standing post-cure at traditional autoclave temperatures to fully cross-link the resin. Process modeling can help design a robust cure cycle to avoid scrapping large parts in production. The focus of this article is to develop the cure kinetics, viscosity, and glass transition temperature models for two commercially available out-of-autoclave epoxy resins. Since the cure kinetics model is the basis for all other thermal models, the cure kinetics model was validated using a one-dimensional heat transfer analysis on thick prepreg laminates. Finally, the out-of-autoclave resin models were compared to a traditional autoclave resin system to highlight the difference in resin reactivity for out-of-autoclave processing.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, out-of-autoclave prepreg technology has advanced to a point where autoclave quality is within reach, even though the maximum consolidation pressure is one atmosphere – applied by a vacuum bag. The reduced pressure of the vacuum bag can produce low void content composite laminates because of controlled resin impregnation techniques. With out-of-autoclave prepregs, porous regions are created by applying the resin to the outer surfaces of the prepreg.1,2 As a result, the vacuum bag can accomplish two tasks simultaneously, first, remove entrapped air within the uncured laminate stack, and second, provide enough consolidation pressure for the resin to flow into the dry regions during elevated temperature processing. If all entrapped air is removed from the laminate stack, the risk of void nucleation and growth is unlikely during cure because out-of-autoclave resins release few volatiles.

Out-of-autoclave prepregs are intended for an initial cure over a wide range of low temperatures: 80–130°C, followed by a free-standing post-cure at 180°C.3,4 Most out-of-autoclave prepregs are subject to an extended room temperature vacuum hold, during which entrapped air is removed from the laminate through vacuum evacuation. During this evacuation process, little or no resin flow should occur to prevent closing the gas evacuation pathways. After the vacuum hold, the laminate is heated to the cure temperature. During the initial cure, resin viscosity must be sufficiently low to fully impregnate remaining dry fiber regions before the resin begins to gel and any remaining voids are locked in. It is therefore very important to get the right viscosity evolution during the vacuum hold and cure in order to achieve void free laminates. The viscosity behavior can be determined by the laminate time and temperature history, and resin cure kinetics. The cure kinetics will also determine the resin degree-of-cure after the initial cure. The degree-of-cure, and corresponding glass transition temperature, must be sufficiently high so that the composite part can maintain dimensional stability once removed from the tool. At this point in the manufacturing process, the part is returned to the oven, and is post-cured up to 180°C to increase the glass transition temperature and resin modulus. During the post-cure, the part glass transition temperature must remain above the oven temperature, otherwise the resin will soften and the part may deform – requiring repair or disposal. To avoid this, an accurate glass transition temperature model is needed to select a suitable ramp rate from the cure temperature up to 180°C post-cure. The performance target of 180°C comes from traditional autoclave resin systems, where primary structures were typically cured at 180°C to boost their glass transition temperatures toward 190°C.5 This specific cure temperature of 180°C enabled the reactivity of autoclave resins to be tailored for a small cure temperature range, and as a result, guarantee a good balance of flow time at low viscosity and short cure cycles. In contrast to autoclave systems, out-of-autoclave resins must be reactive over a broad temperature range, severely influencing resin degree-of-cure and flow behavior.

Thermal models are often used to predict resin behavior (cure kinetics and resin flow) for a given cure cycle, in order to aid in process development. A cure kinetics model can be used in conjunction with a thermal heat transfer model to predict the temperature evolution during cure of a composite part and tool, when the part-tool assembly is placed inside an oven or autoclave with known convective heat transfer characteristics. The role of the kinetics model in predicting the temperature evolution is used to account for the exothermic heat generated by the curing process. In thick composite parts, there is significant risk that the heat generated by the exothermic cure reaction may cause the temperature inside the composite to exceed allowable temperature limits, possibly degrading the material if care is not taken in designing suitable temperature ramps, tooling thermal characteristics, and convective heat transfer conditions.

To aid in resolving these processing issues, the cure kinetics, viscosity, and glass transition temperature were measured and modeled for two commercial out-of-autoclave resin systems. The subject of fitting models to thermal data has been extensively covered in the literature.6–11 Therefore, this article uses the techniques presented in the literature to conduct the experiments and fit material models to experimental data. Few techniques have been presented to validate the cure kinetics models developed from dynamic scanning calorimeter (DSC) data. Cure kinetics models are typically validated with the original DSC data, but a drawback of this approach is that DSC samples are small (a few milligrams), and the samples may not be representative of full-sized composite laminates.12 A method to validate cure kinetics models with thermal heat transfer in composites processing has been proposed by Slesinger et al.,13 and will be used in this study to validate the developed cure kinetics models. The cure kinetics models will be used to further develop viscosity and glass transition temperature models for this new class of out-of-autoclave prepreg resins.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Two commercially available out-of-autoclave toughened epoxy resin systems were used in this study. The first system was ACG MTM®45-1 by the Advanced Composites Group Ltd, and the second was Cycom®5320 by Cytec Engineered Materials Inc. For brevity, the systems will be referred to as MTM45-1 and 5320 in this article. For cure kinetics and viscosity characterization, neat resin film was used, and for the cure kinetics validation and glass transition temperature characterization, prepreg was used. To maintain similar out-time between samples, the materials were tested within 24 h of being removed from storage in a freezer that was kept below −10°C.

sec.title: Model development
sec.p:
With the combination of a DSC and a phenomenological model, it is possible to predict the cure behavior of thermosetting resins.14 In this study, a TA Instruments Q100 DSC was used to measure the heat flow of resin samples in dynamic and isothermal conditions. Four ramps were performed at 2°C/min to obtain the total heat of reaction of the resins. Additionally, six isothermal dwells were performed over the processing window to obtain the experimental cure rate and degree-of-cure. The isothermal tests were held at constant temperature until the sample heat flow approached zero. Each isotherm was repeated twice, and a summary of all DSC tests is presented in Table 1. Table 1.
Conditions for MTM45-1 and 5320 DSC and rheology experiments
Test MTM45-1 5320
DSC ramp (°C/min) 2 2
DSC isotherm (°C) 80, 100, 120, 140, 160, 180 80, 100, 120, 140, 160, 180
Rheometer ramp (°C/min) 1, 2. 3, 4 0.6, 1.7, 2.8, 5.6
Rheometer isotherm (°C) 80, 100, 120, 140 93, 107, 121, 149
DSC: dynamic scanning calorimeter.

To extract the cure rate from the DSC data, measured heat flows were converted into cure rates using the techniques presented by Khoun et al.6 The first step was to use the dynamic DSC data to calculate the total heat of reaction. The DSC heat flow signal was plotted as a function of time, and a linear integration of the area under the heat flow curve was used to calculate the total heat of reaction for each system: 368.9 ± 3.4 J/g for MTM45-1 and 529.9 ± 4.0 J/g for 5320. The second step was to compute the experimental cure rate for each isothermal dwell. By assuming the cure rate was proportional to the measured heat flow, the experimental cure rate for each time step in every isotherm was computed as follows (1)dαdt=1QTdQdt where dα/dt is the cure rate, QT the total heat of reaction, and dQ/dt the heat flow from the DSC. The experimental degree-of-cure, α, was obtained by integrating equation (1).

A cure kinetics model was fit to the experimental data using the process outlined in Khoun et al.6 The initial degree-of-cure of the resin was assumed to be 0.01, and then the cure rate was predicted based on the current degree-of-cure and temperature. One model used to describe the curing behavior of thermosetting resins was by developed by Kamal and Sourour15 (2)dαdt=Kαm(1-α)n where K is the Arrhenius temperature dependency (3)K=Aexp(-EART).

In equations (2) and (3), EA is the activation energy of the resin and A, m, and n are constants. The activation energy of each resin was calculated by measuring the slope of ln (dα/dt) versus 1/T for low degrees-of-cure (α < 0.1), and all other constants were determined using a weighted least squares curve fit with the experimental data. The shape of equation (2) is a bell curve, and did not adequately describe the experimental data. Another model used for thermosetting resins includes a diffusion factor developed by Cole et al.,16 to account for the shift from kinetics to a diffusion controlled reaction as the degree-of-cure increases above gelation. The model is (4)dαdt=Kαm(1-α)n1+exp(D(α-(αC0+αCTT))) where D is the diffusion constant, αC0 the critical degree-of-cure at absolute zero, and αCT accounts for the increase in critical degree-of-cure with temperature. As shown in Figure 1, the model described by equation (4) captured the overall trend of the MTM45-1 reaction, particularly the diffusion at higher degrees-of-cure, but could be improved. In Figure 1, a faster cure rate exists in the experimental data at low degrees-of-cure (α < 0.1). To account for this additional reaction at low degrees-of-cure, equation (2) was added to equation (4), resulting in (5)dαdt=K1αm1(1-α)n1+K2αm2(1-α)n21+exp(D(α-(αC0+αCTT))). Figure 1.
Comparison of equations (4) and (5) predicted cure rates with DSC data for MTM45-1 at 120°C. DSC: dynamic scanning calorimeter.

Equation (5) is also plotted in Figure 1, and the improvement in fit quality is better with equation (5). In Figure 2, the additional reaction at low degrees-of-cure is apparent in the 120°C isotherm for 5320. The high cure rate at low degrees-of-cure causes the cure rate to peak just above a degree-of-cure of 0.1, before following a more traditional autoclave epoxy system curing behavior for the remainder of the reaction. To identify the contribution of equations (2) and (4) to capture the complex curing process summarized by equation (5), all three models are presented with the experimental cure behavior of 5320 in Figure 2. For these out-of-autoclave systems, the principal reaction is described by equation (4), and the spike in cure rate at low degrees-of-cure is described by equation (2). Figure 2.
Measured and predicted cure rate for Cycom 5320 at 120°C. The model, equation (5), is decomposed to show the contribution from equations (2) and (4).

To illustrate the effectiveness of the cure kinetics model developed with equation (5), the experimental and predicted cure rate for MTM45-1 is presented in Figure 3 and for 5320 in Figure 4. For clarity of the low temperature cure rates, the cure rates are only shown for 80–140°C cure range. The model predicts the MTM45-1 cure rate with excellent precision over the cure range. The fit for 5320 is excellent at cure temperatures below 120°C, but as the cure temperature increase toward 140°C, the model prediction deviates slightly from the experimental data, but has a comparable shape. Overall, the curing behavior of the resins is accurately described by equation (5), with the parameters in Table 2. Figure 3.
Measured and predicted cure rate for MTM45-1 resin. Figure 4.
Measured and predicted cure rate for 5320 resin. Table 2.
Parameters for MTM45-1 and 5320 resin cure kinetics models
Parameter MTM45-1 5320
A1 (s−1) 2.53 × 104 8.23 × 107
EA1 (J/mol) 60,628 82,375
m1 0.55 0.75
n1 21.11 12.46
A2 (s−1) 4.84 × 104 1.04 × 105
EA2 (J/mol) 61,752 62,355
m2 0.80 0.90
n2 1.18 2.07
D 44.3 40.4
αC0 −1.4 −1.12
αCT (K−1) 5.33 × 10−3 4.53 × 10−3

sec.title: Model validation
sec.p:
Model validation followed the method developed by Slesinger et al.13 To validate the cure kinetics models, thick laminates were laid-up and thermocouples were placed inside the laminate at different locations in the thickness direction, as shown in Figure 5. The laminates were thermally insulated with silicone rubber and breather material to create a one-dimensional heat transfer problem. The instrumented laminate was subjected to the same heating cycle, twice. During the first heating cycle, the laminate was cured and the heat released during the exothermic reaction was detected with the embedded thermocouples. During the second heating cycle, the heat transfer mechanisms were identical to the first cycle, with the exception of the exothermic reaction caused by resin curing. By comparing the two data sets, the effect of the cure exotherm was evaluated. A one-dimensional conductive heat transfer model was then created based on the geometry shown in Figure 5d. The model includes a term for exotherm heat generation due to cure of the composite material, using the cure kinetics models developed in this paper. The thermal model parameters were validated using the temperature data from the second heating cycle, and the cure kinetics models were validated using the temperature data from the first heating cycle. Figure 5.
Experimental setup and bagging of validation samples. (a) Lay-up stack. (b) Sides enclosed by breather layers. (c) Cross-sectional illustration of thermocouple placement in lay-up stack. (d) One-dimensional model of lay-up stack (not to scale): (1) set-temperature boundary; (2) rubber brick material model (16 mm); (3) FEP material model (0.02 mm); (4) peel-ply material model (0.1 mm); (5) laminate material model (30- and 50-ply samples are 12 and 20 mm thick, respectively). Red arrows indicate direction of autoclave heat flow, while orange arrows indicate direction of exotherm heat flow. FEP: fluorinated ethylene propylene.

Cure modeling simulations were performed using RAVEN, a cure simulation software that can evaluate material and thermal process states based on the cure cycle and material lay-up.17 The thermo-physical data for the materials used in the simulation (Figure 5d) are presented in Table 3, and were either derived from DSC data, experimental nominal values, or from manufacturer’s data sheets. Further discussion regarding the theory and development behind the validation method can be found in Slesinger et al.13 Table 3.
Thermo-physical properties of materials used in the simulations
Material properties Shin-Etsu KE1204 RTV silicone rubber FEP film Peel-ply MTM45-1 5320
Density (kg/m3) 1540a18 1720.0b 1600.0b 1180a3 1310a4
Specific heat (J/kg·K) 1050b 775.0b 900.0b 1200–1360bc 1260b
Conductivity (W/m·K) 0.53b 0.5b 0.1b 0.20b 0.167b
FEP: fluorinated ethylene propylene.
DSC: dynamic scanning calorimeter. a
Values obtained from manufacturer’s datasheet. b
Values obtained from DSC testing, or are nominal values based on experiments. c
Values varying with degree-of-cure (α = 0.001 to 1).

Validation laminates consisted of 30 plies of 5320 and 50 plies of MTM45-1, laid-up in 100 × 100 mm2, and were prepared according to the manufacturer’s recommended lay-up procedures.3,4 Thermocouples were placed throughout the thickness of the laminates and the laminates were wrapped in a layer of peel-ply, followed by a layer of perforated fluorinated ethylene propylene film to prevent excessive resin bleed while still allowing any potential volatiles to escape. The laminates were then sandwiched between two thick silicone rubber bricks (KE1204 RTV from Shin-Etsu), with each brick containing thermocouples at 3 mm intervals through the thickness. Finally, the side surfaces were wrapped with several layers of low thermal conductivity breather cloth to minimize any heat transfer at the edges of the laminates. The assemblies were envelope-bagged, and heated to their respective manufacturer’s recommended cure cycles. Both heating cycles were conducted with full vacuum applied within the vacuum bag. Thermal data from the second (cured) run were analyzed first. The thermal response of the cured composite was compared to the simulation results to validate thermo-physical model properties that are unaffected by resin cure. Experimental and simulated part temperatures for MTM45-1 and 5320 samples during their fully cured (second heating cycle) states are shown in Figure 6. During the heating cycle, the maximum difference in measured and simulated temperature for the MTM45-1 laminate was 1.3°C, and 0.5°C for the 5320 laminate. Since the simulations follow the experimental data so closely throughout the entire cycle, the thermal models and thermo-physical inputs for the cured laminates (density, volume fraction, thermal conductivity, and specific heat capacity) were considered validated. The difference in the thermal response from the second (cured composite) and first (curing composite) heating cycles was mainly due to internal heat generation caused by resin cure. Figure 6.
Experimental and simulated part temperatures for 50-ply cured MTM45-1/CF2426A laminate (left) and for a 30-ply cured 5320/T650 laminate (right).

Validation of the cure kinetics models for both the MTM45-1 and 5320 resin systems was done by comparing experimental and simulated responses from the first (curing composite) heating cycles. Experimental and simulated part temperatures for the curing MTM45-1 laminate are shown in Figure 7 and the 5320 curing laminate in Figure 8. Examining the simulated and experimental data shows that the simulations lag slightly behind the experiments during heat-up and over-predict the exotherms slightly for both resin systems. The MTM45-1 simulation peak exotherm occurred 12 min (4% error) after the experimental peak exotherm, and the simulation predicted a higher maximum temperature of 2.7°C (2% error) compared to experiments. The simulated 5320 peak exotherm occurred 10 min (4% error) before the experimental data, and over-predicted the peak temperature by 1.6°C (1% error). The average hold temperature in the oven used to cure the samples was 123.5°C. The small fluctuations in the hold temperature seen in Figures 7 and 8 are real and due to the temperature controller of the oven. Figure 7.
Experimental and simulated part temperatures for 50-ply curing MTM45-1/CF2426A sample. Figure 8.
Experimental and simulated part temperatures for 30-ply curing 5320/T650 sample.

Both experiments and simulations are associated with some error and uncertainty. The thermocouples used have an accuracy of ±2°C.19 Inaccuracies in the simulations may be due in part to simplifications in the physics of the models, for example, resin flow and fiber bed consolidation phenomena were not simulated during cure. Additional errors can be introduced from the neat resin used to create the cure kinetics model and the prepreg used to validate the model. First, the neat resin film used in DSC testing was from a different batch than the woven prepreg material used for validation. Second, the carbon fibers in the prepreg are coated with an epoxy sizing to aid in bonding the MTM45-1 and 5320 resins to the fiber. The influence of the sizing on the resin cure behavior was not studied. Finally, minor variations in material out-time between the neat resin and prepreg may contribute to the simulation leading and over-predicting the measured experimental exotherm.

In the aerospace industry, where these prepregs are used, the objective in thermal management is to keep the part temperature within a tolerance band of the nominal cure temperature, defined in the cure cycle specifications for the material, in order to achieve consistent mechanical and physical properties from part-to-part.13 The temperature tolerance band can be as low as ±6°C during a temperature hold.4 If part temperatures are beyond the temperature tolerances, the design allowables may no longer apply and the part has to be scrapped. If thermocouple errors are ±2°C, the simulations have to be within ±4°C of experimental data to guarantee that simulations are within ±6°C of the true temperature. The MTM45-1 and 5320 thermal models developed in this article meet this condition for the validation case. The validation procedure demonstrated that the cure kinetics models are sufficiently accurate, and that the models can be incorporated with a heat transfer model to simulate the actual temperature of thick laminates during cure.

sec.title: Rheology
sec.p: Using an approach similar to cure kinetics, a viscosity model was created by performing experiments with a rheometer, and fitting a semi-empirical model to the data.20 An AR 2000 Rheometer by TA Instruments, equipped with an Environmental Test Chamber, was used to measure the change in complex viscosity in dynamic and isothermal conditions. Four different ramp rates were selected for the dynamic tests, and four isothermal dwells for each resin system. Each test was repeated twice, and the rheology test matrix is presented alongside the DSC tests in Table 1. The tests were performed in oscillatory mode by inducing a small amplitude oscillatory strain at 1 Hz into a 0.5–1 mm thick resin sample, mounted between two 25 mm diameter parallel plates. The rheology tests were conducted in the linear viscoelastic region using a controlled strain of 0.1% for MTM45-1 and 0.25% for 5320.

A model to describe the resin viscosities was created according to the techniques presented by Khoun et al.6 They modified a viscosity model incorporating gel effects, originally developed by Castro and Macosko.21 Their model includes an additional Arrhenius temperature dependency and an additional polynomial term to better describe the viscosity at gelation. The viscosity model is (6)η=η1+η2(αgelαgel-α)A+Bα+Cα2 where α is the instantaneous degree-of-cure predicted using equation (5), αgel the degree-of-cure at gelation, A, B, and C are constants, and ηi the Arrhenius temperature dependency (7)ηi=Aηiexp(EηiRT), i=1,2 where Eηi is the viscosity activation energy, Aηi a constant, R the universal gas constant, and T the absolute temperature. Eηi was taken as the slope of the linear line of best fit through a plot of ln (μ) versus 1/T, from room temperature until the viscosity began increasing. The degree-of-cure at gelation, was determined by averaging the degree-of-cure when tan(δ) = 1 in each of the dynamic and isothermal tests. All other constants were calculated using a weighted least squares curve fit with the experimental data. The MTM45-1 and 5320 model constants are summarized in Table 4. Table 4.
Parameters for MTM45-1 and 5320 resin viscosity models
Constant MTM45-1 5320
Aµ1 (Pa·s) 1.8 × 10−5 8.0 × 10−13
Eµ1 (J/mol) 42.050 93.931
Aµ2 (Pa·s) 6.9 × 10−13 2.9 × 10−11
Eµ2 (J/mol) 95.710 83.400
αgel 0.40 0.48
A 6.3 3.2
B −9.9 12.7
C 9.4 −29.6

The measured dynamic viscosity and the model prediction for MTM45-1 are shown in Figure 9. There is good agreement between the model and experiments until 130°C, where the model has difficulty capturing the minimum viscosity and gel of temperature ramps greater than 1°C/min. Between 130°C and 150°C, the experimental viscosity remained fairly constant, even though the temperature was increasing. An improvement in this range was possible, but at the expense of the isothermal viscosity fit. The agreement between the model and isothermal experiments for MTM45-1 is shown in Figure 10. The model successfully captures the increase in viscosity over the wide processing temperature range of the material. Since out-of-autoclave materials are intended for an initial cure below 130°C, the model will capture the change in viscosity during the ramp and constant temperature hold of the cure cycle. In the unlikely case that the resin is initially cured above 130°C, the model would underestimate the minimum viscosity and gel time for MTM45-1. As for MTM45-1, the model has a similar difficulty predicting the minimum viscosity above 130°C in dynamic conditions for 5320, but does capture gelation for all four temperature ramps (Figure 11). As well, the change in viscosity of the 5320 resin is effectively captured by the model for all four constant temperature holds (Figure 12). The 5320 gel time is slightly overestimated for the lower temperature isotherms, and underestimated at the highest. If the materials are initially cured within the 80–130°C temperature range, the viscosity models provide a sufficiently accurate description of the evolution of the viscosity from room temperature up to gelation. Figure 9.
Measured and predicted dynamic viscosity for MTM45-1 resin. Figure 10.
Measured and predicted isothermal viscosity for MTM45-1 resin. Figure 11.
Measured and predicted dynamic viscosity for 5320 resin. Figure 12.
Measured and predicted isothermal viscosity for 5320 resin.

sec.title: Rheology validation
sec.p:
To validate the experimental data presented in this study, the measured data were compared with available thermal data from the manufacturers. The only published data available for both materials are viscosity temperature ramps.3,4 The available manufacturers’ viscosity data are plotted with the experimentally measured viscosity in Figure 13. The evolution of the measured viscosity follows the manufacturers’ data quite well up to 100°C. Above 100°C, the measured viscosity is 3–5 Pa·s higher, and gelation occurs at 4–5°C before the manufacturers’ viscosity profiles. This trend was observed for both MTM45-1 and 5320 resins. Some of the deviation may be associated with inaccuracies extracting the manufacturers’ viscosity values from the data sheets,3,4 but the most likely cause of the discrepancy is the variation in material out-time between the resin tested by the manufacturers, and the resin tested in this study. The resins were tested in this study before their expiration date, but they have a thermal history – manufacture, transportation, freeze-thaw cycles, and room temperature handling. Given that these resins would likely encounter similar thermal histories in a composites production environment, the viscosity behavior of the resins is similar to the profiles reported by the manufacture, within the shelf-life of the materials. Figure 13.
Measured viscosity (lines) and manufacturer’s viscosity (symbols) extracted from Advanced Composites Group Ltd3 and Cytec Engineered Materials.4

sec.title: Glass transition temperature
sec.p:
The glass transition temperature model was developed by testing pre-cured laminates using Dynamic Mechanical Analysis (DMA), and fitting the experimental data to the model developed by DiBenedetto.22 Two plies of prepreg were stacked and cured in an oven for each resin system. Samples were cured at five different temperatures and the temperature was recorded with a K-type thermocouple. After curing, the samples were tested in three-point bending in a Q800 DMA by TA Instruments. The samples were subjected to 100 µm sinusoidal displacements at a frequency of 1 Hz, while the furnace was heated at 2°C/min. The glass transition temperature was taken at the onset of the change in the storage modulus for each sample. Three samples were tested for each temperature, and the average glass transition temperature is presented in Figure 14. The model fit to the data is (8)Tg-Tg0Tg∞-Tg0=λα1-(1-λ)α where Tg0 is the glass transition temperature of the uncured resin, Tg∞ the glass transition temperature of the fully cured resin, and λ the experimentally determined constant. The glass transition temperature of the uncured resin was measured with a DSC by increasing the temperature from −40°C to room temperature. The onset of the transition in heat capacity was taken as the glass transition temperature of the uncured resin. A summary of the parameters for each resin is presented in Table 5. To complete the glass transition temperature model, the degree-of-cure for each sample was predicted with the recorded thermocouple data and cure kinetics models presented earlier. The resin glass transition temperature models are presented alongside the experimental data in Figure 14, and nicely capture the evolution of the glass transition temperature with degree-of-cure. Figure 14.
The measured and predicted glass transition temperature for MTM45-1 and Cycom 5320 resins. Table 5.
Parameters for MTM45-1 and 5320 glass transition temperature models
Constant MTM45-1 5320
Tg0 (°C) −8.6 −8.4
Tg∞ (°C) 210 212
λ 0.83 0.66

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The thermal models presented in this article can be used to effectively describe the cure kinetics, viscosity, and glass transition temperature evolution of the resins for any time-temperature history. This can be a useful tool to design cure cycles that enable sufficient resin flow so the fibers become saturated, and then the resin is polymerized to an acceptable degree-of-cure. Since out-of-autoclave resins are reactive at lower temperatures, less time may be available for the resin to fully saturate the dry fibers. In autoclave processing, a conventional approach to achieve full fiber wetting is to have an intermediate dwell at a lower temperature, to allow the resin to properly wet-out the fibers before proceeding to fully cure the resin at a higher temperature.5 An example of this can be found in the recommended cure cycle for the toughened aerospace prepreg epoxy resin made by Hexcel, HexPly®8552.23 The 8552 resin system is well established on rotary wing military aircraft, and is a benchmark for out-of-autoclave resins.24 Given that 8552 was designed to be cured in an autoclave at 180°C, this allowed for a low reaction rate at the recommended 107°C dwell temperature. Since out-of-autoclave prepregs are designed to be cured at temperatures previously reserved for resin flow in autoclave processing, the degree-of-cure may advance too quickly, reducing resin flow time. Figure 15 shows the increase in degree-of-cure for MTM45-1, 5320, and 8552 during a 120°C hold after a 1°C/min ramp from room temperature. The cure kinetics and viscosity for 8552 was modeled by Hubert et al., 11 and is used for comparison with the MTM45-1 and 5320 resins. Figure 15 shows the major difference in degree-of-cure evolution at low temperatures between out-of-autoclave and autoclave resin systems. Since the MTM45-1 and 5320 resins are reactive at 120°C, the increase in degree-of-cure allows for similar cycle times as autoclave processing. On the other hand, the increased resin reactivity at low temperatures may negatively influence resin flow – leading to defects, such as porosity and dry spots. Figure 15.
Evolution of the degree-of-cure for MTM45-1, Cycom 5320, and HexPly 8552 resins subjected to a 1°C/min temperature ramp to 120°C. The out-of-autoclave resins (MTM45-1 and 5320) are more reactive at lower temperatures than 8552.

Resin flow time is presented as a function of cure temperature in Figure 16 for the out-of-autoclave (MTM45-1 and 5320) and autoclave (8552) systems. A one-step cure cycle (similar to the one shown in Figure 15) was used with a temperature ramp at 1°C/min to the cure temperatures. The resin flow time was defined as the time during the simulated cure cycle when resin viscosity was below 100 Pa·s. Since 8552 is less reactive at lower temperatures, intermediate dwells can be used in the cure cycle to ensure enough resin flow occurs. A maximum of 60–120 min of flow time is available for out-of-autoclave prepreg resins. As a result, thermal gradients on large parts and fiber beds with high permeabilities may be more susceptible to dry regions and porosity in out-of-autoclave processing – especially since consolidation pressures are lower. Figure 16.
Resin flow time – the total time that the resin viscosity is below 100 Pa·s – during cure cycles where the temperature was ramped at 1°C/min to the cure temperature. The 8552 (autoclave) system has a longer flow window than the 5320 or MTM45-1 (out-of-autoclave) systems.

An accurate glass transition temperature model is more important in out-of-autoclave processing than in autoclave processing because of the necessary free-standing post-cure. If the glass transition temperature is crossed during post-cure, permanent deformation of the part could occur, especially on large contoured structures. To avoid part deformation, the temperature ramp during the post-cure must be slow enough to advance the resin glass transition temperature ahead of the oven temperature. In Figure 17, the glass transition temperature is plotted for an oven temperature ramp of 0.25 and 1°C/min. The 1°C/min temperature ramp was too fast, causing the glass transition temperature to cross the oven temperature. The slower 0.25°C/min ramp rate would prevent any temperature cross-over, and avoid any stress relaxation that could permanently deform the composite structure. Figure 17.
Evolution of the glass transition temperature for two different temperature ramp rates during a post-cure from 120°C (initial cure temperature) to 180°C. Only 5320 is shown for clarity, but MTM45-1 behaves similarly. Initially, the glass transition temperature is above the oven temperature, but falls below the air temperature for higher heating rates. This could lead to part deformation during a free-standing post-cure.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Together, cure kinetics, viscosity, and glass transition temperature are an important first step toward defining a suitable cure cycle for out-of-autoclave prepreg processing. To aid in this, models describing these properties were developed for MTM45-1 and 5320 out-of-autoclave prepreg resins. Out-of-autoclave prepregs are similar to autoclave prepregs in how they are processed – using a bag molding process in an oven. Nevertheless, the resin thermal behavior is quite different for out-of-autoclave prepregs because of their low temperature curing capabilities. Out-of-autoclave resins are initially cured at low temperatures until the degree-of-cure has advanced sufficiently so that the composite can be removed from the tool and post-cured in an oven. To account for the sharp increase in cure rate at low degrees-of-cure, a typical autoclave resin cure kinetics model required an additional cure rate term to accurately describe the cure reaction over a wide temperature range: 80–180°C. Since the cure kinetics model is the basis for all other thermal models, the kinetics model developed with small resin samples was validated using thick prepreg laminates. The heat generated by the curing reaction was measured experimentally, and compared with a heat transfer simulation of a curing composite laminate. The experiments and simulations confirmed that the cure kinetics model derived from small resin samples was scalable to thick composite laminates.

The degree-of-cure also influences the resin flow behavior and the glass transition temperature. Resin flow is important in out-of-autoclave prepregs since they are supplied partially impregnated, and impregnation must be completed during cure, with less consolidation pressure, to produce porosity-free laminates. Since the degree-of-cure advances quickly at low temperatures, the flow time is reduced to 60–120 min for out-of-autoclave resins. That may seem long, but autoclave resins can have 200–500 min of flow time in the same temperature range – allowing for full wet-out of large parts. The reduced flow time emphasizes the importance of accurate thermal models to develop cure cycles that can evacuate the laminate and allow the resin to impregnate the dry fiber regions before gelation. After gelation, the part is post-cured to fully develop the resin physical and mechanical properties. The post-cure requires an accurate glass transition temperature model to identify a suitable ramp rate to the post-cure temperature to avoid part deformation. The temperature ramp may require a ramp rate as slow as 0.25°C/min – a time consuming restriction, necessary to avoid part deformation.

sec.p: None declared.
